design_add_fac: i will say that for me personally, anything a user says or does publicly on social media is fair game as is contacting them if the settings they've chosen allow it these things are part and parcel of using social media, and don't need or deserve any notification or compensation however, when you start to collect private information, install software, or anything else beyond the expected scope of regular social media interactions, i think there needs to be much more scrutiny on fair treatment and fair compensation

ethic_appr: Typically, getting ethical approval means running things through an Institutional Review Board (IRB), outlining methods, how data will be used, and how consent will be obtained. They typically must justify why they are collecting the data they're interested in, and how they will ensure that participants will know their risks and benefits and provide informed consent. Most researchers also must complete individual ethics training, for example through CITI.
study_1_conc: this is getting more into public posting, which i find slightly more acceptable than sending a directed private message, but it is still problematic due to not obtaining informed consent or providing a debriefing to participants any time there's a situation of "didn't know they were in an experiment" gets my ears burning and flashbacks of my citi training because it is public posts being measured though, it gets much closer to observational research i still don't like that it's tied to individual names though, so not quite acceptable
study_1_add_info: if it were a fully deidentified platform with random usernames and no real names associated, it would get into a much more acceptable zone for me, in the context of observational research
study_2_conc: there was no informed consent obtained for this the participants were not aware they were in a research study it also says nothing of being debriefed observational research can fall in a gray area, but it has to be fully anonymous (for example, just counting the number of people who walk across a street in a day would be fine since it doesn't identify individuals at all) if there is any kind of interaction, for example by a confederate or the researcher, the researcher needs to provide debriefing after the fact in this case, there is a name attached to the data (even if later deidentified) and no consent obtained, nor any debriefing
study_2_add_info: not really - they didn't debrief, provide informed consent, or deidentify data this should have failed at the irb
study_3_conc: this sounds like something that went through an irb rather than targeting specific users, they allowed people to come to them through an advertisement they used informed consent procedures and allowed participants to make decisions the browser extension was optional i will say the only thing i find questionable here is the payment amount $5 for 8 weeks of data is shameful to me people need to be paid based on the value of their labor, time, risk, etc, and that amount fails to do so also i really hate the idea that they could essentially pay to see the results (ie, either get paid or know the study results) that is never okay aggregated results must always be available for those who participate and request them
study_3_add_info: i would want to know how invasive the browser software was and on average how much time was spent by each user on average using their social media that would adjust the acceptable rate of pay for me (eg, if they are only using it 5-10 minutes a week, it would be more of a reasonable rate)
study_4_conc: this is observational research done in a fairly public way, so again, i am mostly okay with this, even without informed consent i still think there needs to be debriefing after the observational period as well as a better way of deidentifying the data
study_4_add_info: if there was secretly a debriefing done and a good way of ensuring that the data was never paired with the user's real name (i think this might be unavoidable though on a platform like twitter), then it would be more ethically acceptable
design_add_fac: protection of identity is a big one, as well as providing informed consent i know that is somewhat reflected above, but informed consent is more than just knowing you're being studied, it is opting in with a free choice it is a higher standard to follow ethically

study_1_conc: i'm on the fence about this it's not too intrusive, and yes it was deceptive, it relayed neutral information i just don't like the idea of users not being aware, that a research study is being conducted
study_2_conc: unacceptable this research should be deemed invalid because the messages were unsolicited they were sent out randomly, and those who participated were unaware of the research i think it's really important for someone to consent, and to make sure everyone involved is aware that research is being conducted it's possible to conduct a study, without having to send unsolicited messages, with false intentions to people
study_2_add_info: i have another issue with this those on both the left and right-leaning aisle are guilty of spreading misinformation i think it's disingenuous for the researchers to target only right-leaning users target both the far left and the far right, the dead center, and then come to me with your results
study_3_conc: i don't find anything wrong with this ther users consented to have specific data monitored, and it was used for specific research purposes
study_3_add_info: the only way i would find this unethical is if the software monitored other user activity, outside of what was consented upon
study_4_conc: i find this slightly acceptable because everything was conducted out in the open, in public no one was dm'd privately with unsolicited links

ethic_appr: It means that the researcher submits a proposed study and method to an institutional review board who reads over the proposal to ensure that the researchers are not doing anything that will cause harm and are open about their procedures. Deception must be disclosed and people asked if they are okay with their data being used in the case of deception. Social media type studies may not receive the same scrutiny if all that is going on is observation of existing posts and NO manipulation of the online environment with bots or fictional posts meant to elicit reactions.

study_1_conc: once again, users were not informed that they were part of a studysecondly, based on my experience from reading hate speech, i seriously doubt that a majority of people deleted their "hate" post after reading an empathetic response from a researcher the posts that i most often see deleted are those where someone has posted a reply that shows that the original poster misinterpreted some facts and were provided with correct info the rest of them often enjoy their roles as trolls and do not bother deleting much of anything
study_2_conc: the users were not aware that they were part of the study and very importantly, the study was limited to conservative users only i find that objectionable and wide open for manipulating data and drawing misleading conclusions
study_2_add_info: the researchers should have also tested liberalprogressive users who posted links to liberal websites that were also allegedly "untrustworthy"
study_3_conc: most importantly, the researchers got the approval of their users first at least the users were aware that they were taking part in a study even though, in my mind, they were severely underpaid
study_4_conc: i object to most studies in which users are not informed that they are being studied and that they are being manipulatedsecondly, i would like to see the type of reply that was originally sent this study almost directly contradicts the results reached in the last study in which people deleted their hate speech because they got a link to a fact checking site along with an empathetic responselastly, i now do my own fact checking after learning that quite a few of these fact checkers are deliberately manipulating and distorting info because of their own bias i simply no longer trust the "fact checkers"
design_add_fac: once again my focus, based on my experience on social media along with my interest in doing studiessurveys on prolific, is that users be informed if there is an intent to try to change or manipulate someone's online behaviorstudying posts objectively is one thing, but deliberately trying to get someone to act differently is unacceptable that is what advertisers, political operatives and propagandists do it is may also be why i have seen user activity drop off during this current campaign season too many accounts are being flagged for supposed violations when people have only posted honest questions regarding the facts or truth behind some claim
rank_add_fac_1: all steps should be taken to avoid one-sided bias that will taint the final results for example, asking broad questions regarding opinions on "immigration" without drilling down and asking the same questions about "illegal immigration"

ethic_appr: I think that ethical approval means that the experiments will be conducted in such a way that no party is harmed in any way, shape, or fashion. No negatives will come to either party for the way that these experiments are conducted.
study_1_conc: while i'm not in favor of using what individuals post on social media as a study tool without their consent, it does seem that this study wasn't done to single anyone out rather, this was more of a behavioral study to see how the poster's actions may change after receiving an empathetic reply of sorts for this reason i am neutral in feeling to this study that was conducted

ethic_appr: Ethical approval involves a thorough review of the study by an IRB (if this is an academic institution). This IRB reviews the proposed study with the goal of analyzing the risks and benefits of the proposed study to future participants. If the risks seem to outweigh the benefit, or it appears that the procedures will cause undue harm to participants, it is rejected or revisions are requested.

study_2_conc: some of same concerns from the previous twitter experiment mentioned - mostly around the "then the researchers created human-operated anonymous twitter accounts" - because many users are now hyperaware of fakebotsock accounts and often will not respond to them the same way someone that is an obvious established account

ethic_appr: I would think ethical approval means putting together a proposal including purpose, the hypothesis, support for the theory or whatever you're trying to prove or disprove, then also describing or outlining the methods you are planning on using in order to obtain your data. You may also have to include the proposed questions you are going to ask to make sure the wording is appropriate. You may also have to include any information at the end if you've used deception in order to get your information like using an article that you've made up or fake websites or graphics that were made up in order to get the data that you needed for the experiment.

ethic_appr: I believe that researchers submit their proposed study to their institution's board of ethics. ethic_appr: Hmm, I'm afraid a fuller answer to that could go on for ages and have all kinds of caveats, so I'll attempt a brief answer (and hope I come somewhere close to right): It likely means you're allowed to do just about anything to gather data except outright lie, at least not without providing some sort of information after-the-fact and then allow an opt-out process of some kind. Of course, if data is being gathered anonymously on a social network platform, I'm not altogether sure there would be a satisfactory way to actually contact all the people from which data was gathered in order to inform them after-the-fact, and even if you did, there's no guarantee the same person who was using the keyboard at the time will be the same person who sees/responds-to the after-fact-informing process, or that anyone would respond at all for that matter. Anyway, yeah, lots of caveats ... and I'm not even sure whether I've even come close to correct on any of that as it relates to the question of what "ethical approval" means. :/

ethic_appr: I think "ethical approval" means that the Institutional Review Board has reviewed the proposed purpose and methods of the research and determined that there is little risk of significant harm to research participants.
study_1_conc: i am concerned that participants were included in the study without their consent especially considering that their public twitter behavior was analyzed for a significant length of time
study_2_conc: i am concerned that users were included in the research without their consent, given that they received unsolicited message via anonymous accounts and had their data analyzed i also think that there may be some questionable ethics related to including only conservatives in the study as this could potential result in skewed andor biased results
study_2_add_info: i would be interested to know whether the researchers made it clear (in their study results) that they were targeting conservative users since failing to do so could result in biased conclusions (which i think is an important ethical consideration in research)
study_3_conc: i have some minor concerns regarding the ethics of this study i think the study is somewhat ethically acceptable because participants gave consent to participate in the study however, my concern is that the recruitment process for seeing the study advertisement was a targeted ad, meaning it was based on facebook algorithms which use user data to generate targeted newsad feeds i think this could be a minor privacy violation since users did not give their consent for the researchers to use their facebook data prior to receiving the targeted ad i also think the participants should be entitled to receive a copy of the study results without being required to forfeit their study compensation
study_3_add_info: i am not sure of facebook's data collection process for targeted ads so having more information about how people were targeted for the study might influence my perceptions of the study
study_4_conc: i am concerned that twitter users were included in the study without their consent, especially considering that the researchers used automated, human-looking accounts to mislead the users into thinking that they had received information from a real person
design_add_fac: i am concerned that researchers may be using data from social media to determine target participants for their study (such as facebook ad algorithms) to my knowledge, having ones data collected or analyzed by outside researchers is not included in the user terms of service or consents so even this preliminary data analysis may be inappropriate from a research ethics perspective
rank_add_fac_1: transparency regarding how participants are includedchosen for the research to decrease potential bias in research data and decrease potential for improper application of research findings (this may be related to scientific reproducibility)

There's probably also some level of consideration to whether or not discovery of, or the operation of such an experiment could cause widespread societal effects. (Which might be under the emotional/mental health umbrella.)

Kind of like walking right into someones house, but your invisible and you have to decide where to draw the line - can I steal food? no.. can I watch them having sex? yes.. its a question of approving what they want and need and lying to themselves to say its ok to do so.

ethic_appr: In my opinion, getting "Ethical approval" to run a study means that the study must adhere to certain basic principles - such as respect of people's autonomy (do no harm), beneficence (minimize risk and maximize the potential of benefit) and justice (the benefits of the study should at least partially go to the subjects being studied)
study_1_conc: same as the previous study - twitter users' manipulation without their express informed consent is ethically unacceptable the only difference here is that instead of an automated bot, the replies were generated by anonymous human users, but that does not make it ethically acceptable
study_1_add_info: i would still say it is ethically unacceptable to do this without informed, valid consent of the 1000 twitter users
study_2_conc: in my opinion - this is even worse than the first twitter study - sending unsolicited private messages to twitter users, without them giving informed consent to being part of an experimental study, is completely unethical this also brings up additional concerns about harassment (sexual or otherwise) through dms, etc
study_2_add_info: if i was on this university's irb, i would absolutely reject this study there is no amount of polishing that would convince me to approve this
study_3_conc: the browser extension installed to record the users' news website visits brings strong privacy concerns - what if there are other personal websites (such as tinder) being recorded accidentally as "news" websites? how long will these recordings be stored? will the data be secured?
study_3_add_info: information about how long the (browser extension) data would be stored, and who would have access to the data, whether it would be aggregated and anonymized - if these were laid out clearly and satisfactorily, would make the study ethically acceptable to me
study_4_conc: in my opinion, this study is ethically unacceptable because participants were not even aware they were part of an experimental study even if the study objectives required that the participants not be told certain details (about the bot replying that the tweet is not true, and providing links to a fact-checking website) - at the very minimum the researchers should have informed the twitter users that they had been drawn into the study pool before using such manipulative tactics this is a shameful social experiment, and the university's irb should have rejected it
study_4_add_info: if i were on the irb board of this university - i would reject this study on ethical grounds, no matter what the study design is flawed
design_add_fac: whether the social media users have given their informed, valid consent to be part of the study - is the number one ethical concern other concerns are also important - such as for how long the researchers will store the data, who will have access to it, whether the data is aggregated and de-identified, etc
rank_add_fac_1: no major economic inducement to take part in the study
rank_add_fac_2: minimize threats to social media users mental health by the study manipulations
rank_add_fac_3: inform participants about the study's outcomes after the study has been concluded and analyzed

study_4_add_info: i think it's more ethical to point to trueness or cause and effect if i knew these were contained studies, like how in the world did they choose who to get the hate speech from? was the selector more biased towards clear hate speech or certain ways the hate speech was said? because if there were differences in selection, there might be differences in results i can't take it as a more ethical study if i don't know for sure that there's no accidental bias i think it's ethical to uphold neutrality, because it's helpful to those seeking knowledge to not have to weed bias out

study_2_conc: not sure i understand why you would send a private message to these twitter users to try and improve the quality of the news content  do you intend to that into perpetuity, as twitter users will revert back to their behavior prior to the testi also don’t like that individuals were not told they were participating in a study

design_add_fac: what is the goal of twitter other than being a bully pulpit  if the hope is to somehow change behavior or control the message, that’s never going to happen  if we truly believe in free speech, you have to let people say what they want  it’s up to each individual user as to whether they want to believe the information or move on  i think of it this way…if someone was giving a speech that was just full of inaccuracies and misinformation, we don’t cut them off  they are allowed to speak  as a listener, its up to the individual whether they want to listen to this information or turn the channel can’t sensor the information, right or wrong

ethic_appr: Assurance that the experimenters will use the data and information collected only for the purpose explained in the study. Also, that the person being polled is aware of their rights and redresses, if necessary, by a board or body overseeing the researchers. Generally, that the experiment will cause no foreseeable harm to the people being polled.
study_1_conc: it's concerning that the study misrepresented the nature of the anonymous accounts who replied to the message it's understandable that they wanted sincere reactions to the messages they sent and that informing the recipients they weren't real people could have caused the messages to be disregarded or met with a level of denial, but since there were a range of responses to the original hate speech, i wonder if any of the replies were incendiary, which could cause the original user to get even more emotionally involved, stressed, or angry, which could lead to actual violence or emotional distress i'd imagine if they were trying to measure how people reacted to different messages they would have to have them grouped into at least empathetic, neutral, and contrary types of messages the researchers sent
study_1_add_info: it's hard to judge without seeing the actual content of the messages, so i'd want to see that and who is overseeing the study and how closely it's being monitored
study_2_conc: same as the others, that the subjects were unaware of the experiment i do find the anonymous accounts more acceptable than the human-looking automated accounts
study_3_add_info: it seems the study was forthcoming and transparent and that participants had to opt in to join it, so i can't see any issues, as long as all other processes are in place (eg the study is being overseen, etc)
study_4_conc: while most of the study seems innocuous, for instance, the bot is just replying with a tweet about fact-checking that the user can choose not to click, it's always concerning when the subjects don't know they're part of an experiment and that the automated accounts were apparently made to look like a human user
study_4_add_info: i'd want to make sure the study is only using publicly-made twitter statements and not going any further by looking into other social media sites the user might have linked or any other biographical information that could be discerned

ethic_appr: I think ethical approval means that the experiment has to be deemed as appropriate, safe, and not have long-term consequences.
study_1_conc: it is unacceptable that the users were never made aware that it was a study and the researcher analyzed the user's behaviors for weeks
study_2_conc: it is good that the researchers only examined data that was collected during the experiment period but unacceptable that the users were messaged privately and were not made aware that it was a experiment
study_3_conc: it is good that users were made aware that it was a study and what the users had to do was related to the research topic
study_4_conc: it is good that the researchers only analyzed the users' behaviors for a short period after the experiment but it is not appropriate that the researchers never told the users that it was an experiment
rank_add_fac_1: long-term effects of the experiment

ethic_appr: I think ethical approval is that an academic experiment is run in an ethical way. Meaning that the researchers adhere to ethical standards.
